title: Rodrigues
common: The surname Rodrigues does not have a unique origin, because it is a patronymic meaning "Rodrigo's son". This complexity conducts Américo de Moura to list 18 different Rodrigues' families (de Moura, Américo, 1951, pp. 446-455).

families.name: Rodrigues (Velho) - São Vicente/São Paulo
history: All data we have about this family is present in Brazil (Almeida, João M., 1886, pp. 351-357), and these documents do not bring any information about his origin.

people.name: António Rodrigues
history:
João M. de Almeida resumes the documentation we have and, as consequence what we know about António Rodrigues (Almeida, João M., 1886, pp. 351-357), this project simplifies the reader given the sources cited in the work:
  • He owns land near a Port named Naus (Leite, Serafim, 1956, pp. 461).
  • In his work about São Vicente, Marcos A. Lança informs us about an António Rodrigues' shipyard (Lança, Marco Antônio, 2005, 106-107).
  • The work about Pero Lopes de Sousa's diary also has a citation about António Rodrigues residence being near a Port (Sousa, Pero L., 1927, pp. 203, 208, 392).
  • The Friar Gaspar Madre de Deus informs us that Martim Afonso de Sousa gave the lands near to Tumiaru to António Rodrigues, he also give us information about a "porto de Tumiaru" and gave even more details about the São Vicente region (Madre de Deus, Gaspar, Frei, 2010, pp. 37-38).

When we talk about his family, we do not have documents to prove the relationships, but Priest Jorge Moreira wrote some memories saying "... que com João Ramalho veio Antonio Rodrigues, o qual, diz o author, casara com uma filha de Piquerobi Cacique da aldêa de Hururay." (Madre de Deus, Gaspar, Frei, 1840, pp. 441). Américo de Moura worked with this family, informing that Luiz G. Silva Leme discovered, and published, a manuscript from Captain Diogo Gonçalves Moreira (de Moura, Américo, 1951, pp. 446), these data can be found in the First Volume of Luiz G. Silva Leme's work, where he calls attention that they are contradictory with Pedro Taques' suggestion (Silva Leme, Luiz G., 1904, Volume I, pp. 45-47). In the next generation, I describe how genetic helps us to confirm that at least one of his [possible] daughters are in fact indigenous.

marriages.name: Desconhecida / Antonia Rodrigues
history: According to Jorge Moreira's memories (Madre de Deus, Gaspar, Frei, 1840, pp. 441).

children.name: Garcia Rodrigues
history: According to Diogo Gonçalves Moreira's notes, that could be extracted from Padre Jorge Moreira's memories (de Moura, Américo, 1951, pp. 446), these notes were published by Luis G. Silva Leme (Silva Leme, Luiz G., 1904, Volume I, pp. 45-47).

children.name: Isabel Velho
history: According to Diogo Gonçalves Moreira's notes, that could be extracted from Padre Jorge Moreira's memories (de Moura, Américo, 1951, pp. 446), these notes were published by Luis G. Silva Leme (Silva Leme, Luiz G., 1904, Volume I, pp. 45-47).

people.name: Garcia Rodrigues
history: Américo de Moura describes him affirming that "Considero Garcia Rodrigues vicentino e casado na terra, não sei se uma ou mais vezes, nem com quem..." (de Moura, Américo, 1951, pp. 447), and genetic sequencing of her [possible] daughters show that they cannot have the same mother. The relationship with his hypothetical father is not documented, and we have as the unique reference some genealogical notes letters (Silva Leme, Luiz G., 1904, Volume I, pp. 45-47).

Américo de Moura described what we know about his life, so we only list the sources that confirm them:
  • There are no documents from Santo André da Borda do Campo, but it is still possible to check data from those days through Tito Livio Ferreira's work (Ferreira, Tito Livio, 1944, pp. 72, 124,151,167, 177, 178);
  • His actions in São Paulo Town Hall are listed in "Actas" (Atas Da Câmara da Cidade de São Paulo, 1562-1596, pp. 2, 11, 12, 21, 22, 23, 24, 29, 31, 33, 34, 41, 83, 85, 105, 169);
  • It is also possible to find information in "Registro Geral da Câmara de São Paulo" (Registro Geral da Câmara de São Paulo, Volume VII, pp. 22).
  • A document from Santo André was published in Informativo Arquivo Municipal (100 anos do Arquivo Histórico Municipal: um olhar sobre o precioso acervo, pp. 4);

marriages.name: Isabel Velho
history: According to Pedro T de A. Paes Leme (Paes Leme, Pedro T. de A., 1976, Tomo III, pp. 141) and Luiz G. Silva Leme (Silva Leme, Luiz G., 1904, Volume I, pp. 45-47), probably because the unique Garcia Rodrigues' daughter that we have documentation was named as Isabel Velho.

marriages.name: Desconhecida
history: According to Américo Moura (de Moura, Américo, 1951, pp. 447).
The genetic sequence of mitochondrial DNA (History Tracers (2024): Living Beings) of [possible] descendants proves she has a mitochondrial haplogroup B2 (de Sillos, Luiz Gustavo, 2023, t. 02:12:26).

children.name: Isabel Velho
history: According to Américo Moura (de Moura, Américo, 1951, pp. 448) using documents present in São Paulo Town Hall (Atas Da Câmara da Cidade de São Paulo, 1623-1628, 1915, pp. 255).

children.name: Francisco Rodrigues
history: According to Américo Moura (de Moura, Américo, 1951, pp. 448) using documents present in São Paulo Town Hall (Atas Da Câmara da Cidade de São Paulo, 1623-1628, 1915, pp. 255).

children.name: Antonio Rodrigues
history: He cites his brothers Francisco Rodrigues, Garcia Rodrigues, Jorge Rodrigues and his brother-in-law Diogo Moreira in his inventory (Inventários e Testamentos, 1921, Volume 11, pp. 51).
According to Américo de Moura (de Moura, Américo, 1951, pp. 448 - 449) and Pedro T. de A. Paes Leme (Paes Leme, Pedro T. de A., 1976, Tomo III, pp. 141).

children.name: Garcia Rodrigues
history: According to Antonio Rodrigues' inventory (Inventários e Testamentos, 1921, Volume 11, pp. 51)
According to Américo de Moura (de Moura, Américo, 1951, pp. 449-450) and Pedro T. de A. Paes Leme (Paes Leme, Pedro T. de A., 1976, Tomo III, pp. 141).

children.name: Jorge Rodrigues
history: According to Antonio Rodrigues' inventory (Inventários e Testamentos, 1921, Volume 11, pp. 53).
According to Américo de Moura (de Moura, Américo, 1951, pp. 448) and Pedro T. de A. Paes Leme (Paes Leme, Pedro T. de A., 1976, Tomo III, pp. 141).

children.name: Mecia Rodrigues
history: Américo de Moura (de Moura, Américo, 1951, pp. 448) and Luiz G. Silva Leme's hypothesis (Silva Leme, Luiz G., 1904, Volume VII, pp. 451-452), but Pedro T. de A. Paes Leme did not follow them (Paes Leme, Pedro T. de A., 1976, Tomo III, pp. 141).
She has a mitochondrial haplogroup different from Isabel Velho (de Sillos, Luiz Gustavo, 2023, t. 02:12:26), this means they cannot be sisters with the same parents.

children.name: Isabel Rodrigues
history: Pedro T. de A. Paes Leme does not cite this hypothesis (Paes Leme, Pedro T. de A., 1976, Tomo III, pp. 141) and Américo de Moura rejects it (de Moura, Américo, 1951, pp. 447), but Luiz G. Silva Leme suggests it (Silva Leme, Luiz G., 1904, Volume VII, pp. 470).
The genetic sequence of her descendants confirms she has the same Mécia Rodrigues' mitochondrial haplogroup (de Sillos, Luiz Gustavo, 2023, t. 02:12:26).

Both Jorge Moreira and Antonio Bicudo, her husband, worked together without any impediment in Town Hall (Atas Da Câmara da Cidade de São Paulo, 1562-1596, pp. 227-252), so it is necessary to consider that either she is not Garcia Rodrigues' daughter (de Moura, Américo, 1951, pp. 447), or some laws were too flexible to allow brothers-in-law to work together when only mothers were different (de Sillos, Luiz Gustavo, 2023, t. 02:15:37).

people.name: Isabel Velho
history: It was not possible to find a unique document that proves her existence (de Moura, Américo, 1951, pp. 447), but Pedro Taques says that he could see, and this document informs that she and her husband came from Porto - PT (Paes Leme, Pedro T. de A., 1976, Tomo III, pp. 141).

There is also the hypothesis that both, she and her supposed brother, are indigenous, this hypothesis is incompatible with the Pedro de A. T. Paes Leme hypothesis that they are Europeans. Before the genetic sequence to be discovered, both hypothesis had the same baseline. With the popularization of these tests, the Amarilis Paiva Almeida's son, that would be a [possible] direct descendant of Garcia Rodrigues' [possible] wife, got a complete genetic sequence of his genetic mitochondrial, that was published on YFull (YFULL, YF089441 ; Brazilian Founders (Family Tree DNA)), in this genetic sequence, the mitochondrial genome is given from mother to her descendants. According to Pedro T. de A. Paes Leme's hypothesis, that informs the supposed Isabel Velho came from Porto, the expectation would be to have a mitochondrial genome from Europe. The molecular data of a [possible] Garcia Rodrigues' descendant shows that her origin is Amerindian, and this is not possible in Europe in the 16th century. The genetic sequence of Amarilis Paiva Almeida's son is exactly the same shown by Luiz Gustavo de Sillos for Isabel Rodrigues' descendants (de Sillos, Luiz Gustavo, 2023, t. 02:12:26). These results do not allow us to say nothing about Garcia Rodrigues, but they show that the supposed Isabel Velho is an Indigenous.

The mitochondrial haplogroup B2 (YFULL, YF089441 ; Brazilian Founders (Family Tree DNA) ; de Sillos, Luiz Gustavo, 2023, t. 02:12:26) does not allow considering her an Antonia Rodrigues' daughter, because she had mitochondrial haplogroup A2 (de Sillos, Luiz Gustavo, 2023, t. 00:40:52), but this result does not remove the possibility of Antonio Rodrigues to be her father.

Diogo Luiz de A. P. de Vasconcellos cites Isabel Velho as a descendant of Maria Alvares Cabral, a hypothetical sister of Pedro Alvares Cabral (de Vasconcellos, Diogo Luiz de A. P., 1904, pp. 36). The book does not give additional information about the primary source that sustains the affirmation, so it is not possible to validate it. But, a researched made by Visconde de Sanches Baéna shows this information is not correct (Sanches Baena, Visconde de, 1897, pp. 13 - 21). This hypothesis is also incompatible with her mitochondrial DNA (History Tracers (2024): Living Beings).
Her supposed generation is shown in his supposed brother and husband.

marriages.name: Garcia Rodrigues
history: According to Pedro T de A. Paes Leme (Paes Leme, Pedro T. de A., 1976, Tomo III, pp. 141) and Luiz G. Silva Leme (Silva Leme, Luiz G., 1904, Volume I, pp. 45-47), probably because the unique Garcia Rodrigues' daughter that we have indirect documentation was named as Isabel Velho.

people.name: Mécia Rodrigues
history: The connection wih her parents is an Américo de Moura (de Moura, Américo, 1951, pp. 448) and Luiz G. Silva Leme's hypothesis (Silva Leme, Luiz G., 1904, Volume VII, pp. 451-452), that is a different understanding of Pedro T. de A. Paes Leme (Paes Leme, Pedro T. de A., 1976, Tomo III, pp. 141).
She had a mitocondrial haplogroup different of Isabel Velho (de Sillos, Luiz Gustavo, 2023, t. 02:12:26), so she cannot be her sister, but she still can be her half-sister.

marriages.name: Domingos Gonçalves da Maia
history: It is accepted that this marriage happened, because Luiz G. Silva Leme reports that he had a testament in 1627 "com testamento em 1627" (Silva Leme, Luiz G., 1904, Volume VI, pp. 455), so I suppose that he had access to it, but there was a wrong association with a hypothetical son Garcia Rodrigues Velho, husband of Catarina Dias (Silva Leme, Luiz G., 1904, Volume VII, pp. 452), como descreve-se abaixo.

people.name: Garcia Rodrigues (Velho)
history:
We have two different hypotheses for Garcia Rodrigues' parents, so we show how to use the scientific method to select them:
  • The scientific method starts with the hypotheses:
    • HYPOTHESIS 1: Luiz G. Silva Leme informs that Garcia Rodrigues would be son of Domingos Gonçalves da Maia, "com testamento em 1627" (Silva Leme, Luiz G., 1904, Volume VI, pp. 455), and Mécia Rodrigues, and he had marriage with Catarina Dias (Silva Leme, Luiz G., 1904, Volume VII, pp. 452).
    • HYPOTHESIS 2: Américo de Moura suggests that he is the son of Garcia Rodrigues and a one of his wives, he had marriage with Catarina Dias (de Moura, Américo, 1951, pp. 449-450).
  • After having the hypotheses, it is necessary to look for primary sources that allow to confirm them:
    • HYPOTHESIS 1: it was not possible to find any document to confirm it, so when Luiz G. Silva Leme had access to his supposed father's testament, he could see his name there (Silva Leme, Luiz G., 1904, Volume VI, pp. 455)
    • HYPOTHESIS 2: in "Cartas e Datas de São Paulo", we are informed there "Anno de Nascimento do Nosso Senhor Jesús Cristo de mil quinhentos e noventa e quatro... Garcia Rodrigues e bem assim sua mulher Catharina Dias ... Tabatinguara que ficaram a elle dito Garcia Rodrigues e a seus irmãos por morte e falecimento de seu pae e mãe delle" (Cartas de Datas de Terra (1555-1600), Volume I, pp. 65-66). The Antônio Rodrigues' inventory cites a Garcia Rodrigues, but the document does not inform his wife's name (Inventários e Testamentos, 1921, Volume 11, pp. 51), but in a document selling some "casas" it is informed that "no Anno de Nascimento de Nosso Senhor Jesus Cristo de mil quinhentos e noventa e quatro... Antonio Rodrigues, filho de Garcia Rodrigues, defunto morador nesta dita villa.." (Cartas de Datas de Terra (1555-1600), Volume I, pp. 70-71).
  • The THEORY is made using primary sources and comparing them with the hypotheses.
    • A HYPOTHESIS 1 informs us that Garcia Rodrigues Velho's supposed father was still alive in the year "1627" and the same hypothesis does not list Antônio Rodrigues as his brother, so we can arrive at the initial conclusion that we are talking about homonymous, but we cannot accept any information given as source of truth, so we need to study the HYPOTHESIS 2. Antônio Rodrigues says in his inventory that he had a brother named Garcia Rodrigues. During sells that happened in the year 1594, there was a declaration of both that their parents passed away, and Antônio Rodrigues added that his father's name was Garcia Rodrigues. Additional information, the wife's name, appear in a sell made by Garcia Rodrigues, forcing us to discard momentarily Luiz G. Silva Leme's hypothesis. Q.E.D. (Util new documents appear that can change current understanding, because science always advances with data.)

marriages.name: Catarina Dias
history: According to document of the year 1594 (Cartas de Datas de Terra (1555-1600), Volume I, pp. 65-66).

children.name: Garcia Rodrigues Velho
history: He is cited by different witness in a diligence for Familiar of Holly Office of his great-grandson, and he also appears in the genealogical tree exposed in the documentation (Torre do Tombo, Tribunal do Santo Ofício: Conselho Geral, Habilitações, Pedro, mç. 25, doc. 476, img. 62).
He is cited in a de genere et moribus document of his son (História da Família, 2014, img. 3).

people.name: Garcia Rodrigues Velho
history:
The captain Garcia Rodrigues Velho, as her wife's uncle, André Fernandes, is one of the people that Camargo's family hated, because he helped Pires family

"favoreceu aos Pires"

during the war (Torre do Tombo, Tribunal do Santo Ofício: Conselho Geral, Habilitações, Pedro, mç. 25, doc. 476, img. 28, 67). The hate against him by Camargo's family resulted in two defamation (Torre do Tombo, Tribunal do Santo Ofício: Conselho Geral, Habilitações, Pedro, mç. 25, doc. 476, img. 28, 68 ): the first used his wife, that is Fernandes' descendant, while the second said that he did not become a Priest to be a Jewish person, but in reallity he did not become a Priest because he killed people and made other crimes ( "homicídios e outros delitos").

marriages.name: Maria Betim
history: She appears in her daughter's baptism in the year of 1642 (Torre do Tombo, Tribunal do Santo Ofício: Conselho Geral, Habilitações, Pedro, mç. 25, doc. 476, img. 25).

children.name: Maria Garcia
history: According to her baptism in 1642 (Torre do Tombo, Tribunal do Santo Ofício: Conselho Geral, Habilitações, Pedro, mç. 25, doc. 476, img. 25).

children.name: Garcia Roiz
history: A son that was a Priest (Torre do Tombo, Tribunal do Santo Ofício: Conselho Geral, Habilitações, Pedro, mç. 25, doc. 476, img. 68).

people.name: Maria Garcia
history: She had defamation without any basis of being a Jewish person (Torre do Tombo, Tribunal do Santo Ofício: Conselho Geral, Habilitações, Pedro, mç. 25, doc. 476, img. 21, 45, 51, 145), this event had relationship with the hate against her father, and the brother of her grandmother during the civil war (Torre do Tombo, Tribunal do Santo Ofício: Conselho Geral, Habilitações, Pedro, mç. 25, doc. 476, img. 5, 28, 33, 47, 94, 110, 145). It suggested the reader to study what was written about her mother, because the defamation is explained there.
In a research not finalized, it was discovered that her mitochondrial haplogroup is C1b (subgroup) (de Sillos, Luiz Gustavo, 2023, t. 01:07:10).
Her generation is listed in her husband family.

marriages.name: Fernão Dias Paes
history: According to her grandson's diligence, that has their son baptism (Torre do Tombo, Tribunal do Santo Ofício: Conselho Geral, Habilitações, Pedro, mç. 25, doc. 476, img. 159).

people.name: Isabel Rodrigues
history: There is no explicitly conclusion about her ascendants, as it was already described (de Moura, Américo, 1951, pp. 447; Silva Leme, Luiz G., 1904, Volume VII, pp. 470), but her son Antonio Bicudo declared in his inventory that "sou filho de Antonio Bicudo natural da Ilha de São Miguel e de Izabel Rodrigues natural desta terra" (our emphasis) (Inventários e Testamentos, 1921, Volume 15, pp. 28), and the DNA (History Tracers (2024): Living Beings) sequence of her descendants (YFULL, YF089441 ; Brazilian Founders (Family Tree DNA) ; de Sillos, Luiz Gustavo, 2023, t. 02:12:26), it is possible to affirm that her mother is Indigenous.
On 18th November 1598, because her husband, Antonio Bicudo, was not present ("ausente"), she requested land for São Paulo Town Hall (Registro Geral da Câmara de São Paulo, 1919, Volume 7, pp. 50,51).
Her generation will be exposed in her husband's family, but it is necessary to finish some documentation collection to clarify some details.

marriages.name: Antonio Bicudo
history: According to her son inventory (Inventários e Testamentos, 1921, Volume 15, pp. 28) and document available in São Paulo Town Hall (Registro Geral da Câmara de São Paulo, 1919, Volume 7, pp. 50,51).

people.name: Isabel Velho
history:
Pedro T. de A. Paes Leme suggested she was born in Porto like her parents (Paes Leme, Pedro T. de A., 1976, Tomo III, pp. 141), but genetic sequence does not allow this showing that her mother is an Indigenous (de Sillos, Luiz Gustavo, 2023, t. 02:12:26), so at least her mother is not a European, but this was not the unique doubt about her, and we use scientific method to select her possible father:
  • The scientific method starts with the hypotheses:
    • HYPOTHESIS 1: according to Eugênio de A. da Cunha e Freitas, she would be Paulo Teixeira's daughter (da Cunha e Freitas, Eugênio de A., 1951, pp. 225-226).
    • HYPOTHESIS 2: is accepted by the majority of researchers. According to it, she would be Garcia Rodrigues' daughter (de Moura, Américo, 1951, pp. 448).
  • After having the hypotheses, it is necessary to look for primary sources that allow to confirm them:
    • HYPOTHESIS 1: there is a "prazo" of Vimieiro that talks about the family (Arquivo Distrital do Porto, 1591).
    • HYPOTHESIS 2: her ascendance through Rodrigues is proved in São Paulo records (Atas Da Câmara da Cidade de São Paulo, 1623-1628, 1915, pp. 255). Information available in the canonization document of Priest Saint José de Anchieta enforces this hypothesis, because Maria Moreira informs "Maria Moreira (ouvida a 20 de julho de 1627), natural de São Paulo, com cerca de 60 anos de idade, filha de Jorge Moreira e de Isabel Velho" (Viotti, Hélio A., 1996, 48).
  • The THEORY is made using primary sources and comparing them with the hypotheses:
    • A HYPOTHESIS 1 uses a "prazo" in Portugal, that authors published different information:
      • The information initially shown informs that Paulo Teixeira's wife is not known, and the author lists 5 children for Rui Teixeira and Isabel Velha. He also adds that Rui Teixeira passed away in 1538.
      • Maurício Antonino Fernandes informs a different data, as Manoel Abranches de Soveral shown in his work (Abranches de Soveral, Manuel, 2000), according to him, Melícia Teixeira, Tomaz Fernandes' wife, generated Rodrigo Teixeira, Frutuoso Teixeira, and Paulo Teixeira, so Melícia Teixeira is not her sister. Manuel Abranches de Soveral informs that in Sande, on 21st February 1593, Paulo Teixeira and Maria Marques had marriage.
      • On Geneall web page, it is possible to observe that José Huet de Bacellar transcribes a part of Prof. Souza Lara's book, where it is confirmed the marriage date, but there is divergence about the parents (Bacellar, José H., Geneall). On the web page is also added that the daughter Isabel Velha had marriage with Jorge Moreira.

      The HYPOTHESIS 2 works only with São Paulo documentation. With this available data, it is possible to say that we have a homonymous couple, because if it is accepted that Maria Moreira is a daughter of listed parents by HYPOTHESIS 1, in 1627 we would have a daughter 26 years older than her mother, and this is not possible. Q.E.D. (Util new documents appear that can change current understanding, because science always advances with data.)
Her generation will be described with her husband's family.

marriages.name: Jorge Moreira
history: According to canonization of Saint José de Anchieta (Viotti, Hélio A., 1996, 48).
